attributes.comment:
My comment is intended to voice my objection to USCIS-2006-0044. As I am
certain you are aware, international adoption is an expensive and time consuming
process. This sort of drastic fee increase seems disproportionate. While cost to
the applicant may not seem a sufficient cause for objection, consider the resulting
attendent consequences. It is respectfully submitted that adoptions (both
international and domestic) are something to be encouraged. Our country's
willingness to open its arms to orphans from all countries and ideologies is among
our traits to be most admired. Considering that many families sacrifice nearly to
the breaking point in order to be able to pursue that option, any measure which
drastically increases the fees associated with adotion should be rejected. To the
extent that fee increases are required, they should be implemented on a more
reasonably adjusted basis -- e.g., 5% or even 10% per year -- so that they could
be more easily handled by the financially taxed applicants. As an additional
matter, it seems particularly ironic during the current immigration debate to adopt
a new set of fees that makes it much more difficult for those of us pursuing a form
of legal immigration -- i.e., international adoption. While I intend to pursue this
option regardless, I do not want to see it closed off to other families. Thank you
for your consideration of these objections.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Lee D. Groeneld
